   pressures.  Patient neuro status continued to improve. Patient now
   following commands, opening eyes and responding appropriately to verbal
   stimulus. Reports no pain.  Have not yet been able to wean off the
   ventilator.

   Troponin-T:[**Numeric Identifier 374**]//, ALT / AST:294/568, Alk Phos / T Bili:40/0.9,
   D-dimer:2257 ng/mL, Fibrinogen:367 mg/dL, LDH:777 IU/L, Ca++:6.9 mg/dL,
   Mg++:2.2 mg/dL, PO4:2.1 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment & Plan:63 y/o M with PMHX of MM s/p autologous stem cell
   transplant in 05 presented foot pain and elevated CKs taken the OR
   emergently for fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome, now s/p cardiac
   arrest and emergency tracheotomy.
   .
   # s/p Cardiac Arrest: Etiology unclear, may be due to acute upper
   airway swelling and hypoxia causing cardiac arrest/bradycardia. Pt had
   rapid return of perfusing rhythm.  There was significant concern for
   initial poor neurologic status post code, however, pt has now had
   return of neuro function and following commands. Suspect that meds
   given peri code contributed to poor neuro status initially, now
   clearing.
   - replete lytes aggressively, status post aggressive Ca [**Last Name (LF) 375**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   follow-up repeat labs
   - neuro exams appear to be improving
   - no need for cooling currently
   .
   # Resp failure: Pt was transferred to ICU s/p cardiac arrest with
   emergency trach and was initially requiring alot of support from vent
   to maintain oxygenation but now weaning quickly.  There was likely a
   component of negative inspiratory pressure pulm edema as seen by
   perihilar fullness on CXR.  This is also suggested by the fact that pt
   weaning quickly from initially high O2 requirement. Also with some
   increased secretions from emergency trach and blood in airways.
   Etiology of tongue swelling early on [**10-1**] and impressive upper airway
   edema seen by Anesthesia impeding the ability to re-intubate is
   unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 11**] have some component of airway collapse and tongue swelling
   from hypothyroidis. Baseline, pt is a Mallampati class III and may have
   pharyngeal airway collapse complicating picture.  Now have definite
   airway with trach, will hold off on steroids for now given mild e/o
   immunosuppression.
   - wean oxygen/PEEP as tolerated
   - continue aggressive suction
   - [**Month (only) 202**] RR to improve respiratory alkalosis
   - empiric Abx Vanc/Cefepime/Clinda/Doxy for any possible pericode &
   emergency trach aspiration
   - Alb/atrovent nebs
   - NPO for now, SBT with trach collar in am
   .
   # Compartment Syndrome with abscess: Pt has now had definitive surgical
   intervention with fasciotomy and frank pus found after opening
   compartments.  Deep cultures were sent intra-op
   - continue Vanc/Cefepime/clinda for skin flora and ?immunocomp state,
   will cover gram negatives until cultures return, then narrow Abx
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u ID recs, work up for atypical infections
   - f/u Vasc Surgery recs
   - dressing changes per Vasc
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Pt presented with hyponatremia of unclear etiology, may
   all be secondary to hypothyroidism.  Appears clinically euvolemic to
   hypervolemic currently, no prior h/o SIADH.  Pt having alot of urine
   output currently, it is possible that this hyponatremia & hypochloremia
   is due to volume overload.
   - continue NS IVF
   - serial lytes q6hrs
   - f/u urine lytes & osms
   - continue to treat hypothyroidism
   .
   # Multiple Myelomma: Pt has been on Revlimid which may have been
   contributing to hypothyroidism on admission.  Anemia & thrombocytopenia
   on admission likely due to marrow suppression.
   - holding Revlimid currently
   - f/u Onc recs
   .
   # Elevated CK/Rhabdo: This was likely all secondary to compartment
   syndrome with intracompartment abcess, now s/p fasciotomy
   - continue aggressive IVF, keep UOP>100cc/hr
   - monitor creatinine & f/u renal recs
   - continue local wound care per vasc
   .
   # LFT abnormalities: Elevated transaminases & elevated LDH in setting
   of acute rhabdo. Baseline LFTs normal.  Unclear if this is due to
   atypical infection vs acute rhabdo.
   - trend LFTs
   - f/u hepatitis serologies
   - f/u ID recs & atypical infection work up
   .
   # Anemia: Hct was 34.7 on admission, now down to 25. This is likely
   complicated by underlying abnormal bone marrow on revlimid for MM and
   intra-operative blood loss.
   - transfuse to maintain hct>25
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Pt profoundly hypothyroid with TSH>50 and low T4.
   This may be contributing to tongue swelling on admission.
   - apprec endo consult
   - continue Levothyroxine 200mg IV daily
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now
   - aggressive repletion of lytes
   .
   # Access: Right femoral line placed during code under non-sterile
   conditions, Left PIV and right arterial line.
   - plan to d/c fem line in am
   .
   # PPx: Pneumoboots, H2 Blocker, Colace
   .
   # Code: FULL
   .
   # Dispo: ICU
   .
   # Comm: husband [**Name (NI) 366**] [**Name (NI) 367**] (h) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 370**], (w) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 371**], (c)[**Telephone/Fax (1) 372**]

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient is a 63-year-old male who presented with foot pain and elevated CK levels, leading to an emergent fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome. He subsequently experienced a cardiac arrest, which was likely caused by acute upper airway swelling and hypoxia. The patient was successfully resuscitated and underwent an emergency tracheotomy.

Currently, the patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and is weaning off the ventilator. He is also receiving antibiotics for possible peri-code and emergency tracheotomy aspiration. The patient's neuro status has improved significantly, and he is now following commands, opening his eyes, and responding to verbal stimuli.

The patient's laboratory results indicate hyponatremia, hypochloremia, and elevated CK levels, which may be secondary to hypothyroidism. He also has anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated LFTs, which may be related to his underlying multiple myeloma and Revlimid therapy.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient may experience further respiratory distress due to airway edema, negative inspiratory pressure, and pulmonary edema.
2. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections due to his immunocompromised state, emergency tracheotomy, and prolonged hospitalization.
3. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's elevated CK levels may indicate ongoing rhabdomyolysis, which can lead to acute kidney injury and other complications.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's recent cardiac arrest and hypothyroidism may increase his risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias and cardiomyopathy.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's recent cardiac arrest and hypothyroidism may also increase his risk of neurological complications, such as seizures, stroke, and encephalopathy.
6. Wound complications: The patient's surgical wounds may become infected or develop complications, such as dehiscence or abscesses.
7. Renal failure: The patient's hyponatremia and elevated creatinine levels may indicate underlying renal dysfunction, which may worsen with continued rhabdomyolysis and hypothyroidism.

To address these potential complications, the patient's care plan should include:

1. Close monitoring of his respiratory status and oxygenation.
2. Aggressive antibiotic therapy for possible infections.
3. Continued management of his rhabdomyolysis and renal function.
4. Cardiac monitoring and management of his cardiac status.
5. Neurological monitoring and management of his neurological status.
6. Wound care and monitoring for wound complications.
7. Renal function monitoring and management of his renal status.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Cardiac Arrest**: The patient experienced cardiac arrest due to unclear etiology, possibly related to hypoxia, upper airway swelling, and hypothyroidism. The patient received epinephrine and CPR for 3 minutes, resulting in rapid return of perfusing rhythm.

**Respiratory Failure**: The patient required emergency tracheotomy and was initially requiring significant support from the ventilator. The patient is now weaning quickly from the ventilator, but may still have components of negative inspiratory pressure pulmonary edema and airway collapse.

**Compartment Syndrome with Abscess**: The patient had a fasciotomy and frank pus was found, indicating a deep abscess. The patient is at risk for further infection and may require further surgical intervention.

**Hyponatremia**: The patient presented with hyponatremia of unclear etiology, possibly related to hypothyroidism. The patient is currently euvolemic to hypervolemic and is producing a large amount of urine.

**Elevated CK/Rhabdo**: The patient had elevated CK levels likely due to compartment syndrome with intracompartmental abscess. The patient is at risk for further muscle damage and may require further aggressive IVF.

**LFT Abnormalities**: The patient has elevated transaminases and LDH levels, possibly due to atypical infection or acute rhabdo. The patient's LFTs may continue to worsen.

**Anemia**: The patient has a significant drop in Hct from 34.7 on admission to 21, likely due to underlying abnormal bone marrow on Revlimid for MM and intra-operative blood loss.

**Hypothyroidism**: The patient is profoundly hypothyroid with TSH > 50 and low T4, which may be contributing to tongue swelling on admission.

**Potential Medical Complications**:

* Sepsis
* Pneumonia
* Pulmonary embolism
* Atelectasis
* Fluid overload
* Renal failure
* Hepatic failure
* Hypocalcemia
* Hypomagnesemia
* Hyperkalemia
* Hypophosphatemia

**Plan**:

* Continue aggressive IVF and suctioning
* Monitor creatinine and renal function
* Trend LFTs and consider further workup for atypical infection
* Consider further surgical intervention for compartment syndrome and abscess
* Continue to manage hypothyroidism and hypocalcemia
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and pneumonia
* Consider further workup for pulmonary embolism and atelectasis
* Monitor for signs of fluid overload and hypervolemia
* Continue to manage anemia and consider further transfusions
* Monitor for signs of rhabdo and consider further aggressive IVF
* Continue to monitor for signs of hepatic failure and consider further workup for atypical infection.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 63-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after suffering a cardiac arrest following an emergency tracheotomy. He was initially unresponsive but has since shown improvement in his neurologic status, following commands, and opening his eyes in response to his name.

The patient's respiratory status has improved, and he is weaning off the ventilator. However, he still requires supplemental oxygen and has a respiratory alkalosis. He is at risk for further respiratory complications, including negative inspiratory pressure pulmonary edema and airway collapse.

The patient has a compartment syndrome with an abscess in his left lower extremity, which was treated with a fasciotomy. He is at risk for further complications, including infection and delayed healing.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of hyponatremia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. He is also hypothyroid, which may be contributing to his tongue swelling.

The patient's medical history includes multiple myeloma, which may be contributing to his anemia and thrombocytopenia. He was taking Revlimid, which may have been contributing to his hypothyroidism.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he is still at risk for further respiratory complications.
2. Infection: The patient has a compartment syndrome with an abscess, which increases his risk for infection.
3. Delayed healing: The patient's compartment syndrome and abscess may delay his recovery and increase his risk for further complications.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may lead to further complications, including seizures and coma.
5. Anemia and thrombocytopenia: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia may increase his risk for bleeding and infection.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may lead to further complications, including delayed healing and increased risk of infection.
7. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's elevated CK levels may indicate rhabdomyolysis, which can lead to further complications, including kidney failure.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Weaning off the ventilator and supplemental oxygen.
2. Aggressive suctioning to manage respiratory secretions.
3. Antibiotics to cover possible infections.
4. Wound care and dressing changes to manage the compartment syndrome and abscess.
5. Repletion of electrolytes and fluids to manage hyponatremia.
6. Treatment of hypothyroidism with levothyroxine.
7. Transfusion of blood products to manage anemia and thrombocytopenia.
8. Monitoring of creatinine and renal function to manage rhabdomyolysis.

The patient's care team should closely monitor his condition and adjust his treatment plan as necessary to manage his complications and improve his outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma, hypertension, and hypercholesteremia who presented to the ICU with respiratory failure and cardiac arrest. He underwent an emergent tracheostomy and was sedated and mechanically ventilated. Overnight, his oxygenation improved, and his mental status became more responsive. He received multiple antibiotics, including doxycycline, clindamycin, cefipime, and vancomycin. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.5°C, heart rate of 69 bpm, and blood pressure of 108/62 mmHg. He is receiving IV fluids, and his fluid balance is being closely monitored. His respiratory support includes invasive ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL and a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a critical concern, and weaning from mechanical ventilation should be done cautiously to avoid reintubation.
2. Sepsis/ Abscess: The patient's sepsis and abscess require continued antibiotic therapy and close monitoring for signs of septic shock.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be related to underlying infection, post-arrest physiology, or other factors, and further evaluation with an ECHO is necessary to determine the cause.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia requires close monitoring and treatment with normal saline and follow-up sodium levels.
5. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's rhabdomyolysis requires close monitoring of CPK levels and IV fluid management.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism requires ongoing treatment with synthroid.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's distended abdomen and bowel sounds present may indicate gastrointestinal complications, such as ileus or obstruction, which require close monitoring and treatment.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and treatment of his multiple medical complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma, hypertension, and hypercholesteremia who presented to the ICU after cardiac arrest and respiratory failure. He underwent a fasciotomy and tracheostomy in the operating room. The patient is currently on invasive ventilation, and his oxygenation has improved overnight. He is receiving multiple antibiotics and medications, including doxycycline, clindamycin, cefipime, and vancomycin. The patient has a history of statins and hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to his current condition.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if his oxygenation does not improve or if he develops a respiratory infection.
2. Sepsis: The patient's multiple antibiotics and medications may not be effective in treating his underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis.
3. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's high compartment pressures and rising CPK levels suggest the possibility of rhabdomyolysis, which could lead to acute kidney injury and other complications.
4. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may not be adequately treated, leading to further complications such as fatigue, weakness, and cold intolerance.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to underlying infection or post-arrest physiology, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may worsen if his sodium levels are not adequately replaced, leading to seizures, coma, and even death.
7. VAP: The patient's invasive ventilation and tracheostomy make him susceptible to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which could lead to respiratory failure and sepsis.
8. DVT: The patient's immobility and invasive lines make him susceptible to deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which could lead to pulmonary embolism and other complications.
9. Stress Ulcer: The patient's critical illness and invasive ventilation make him susceptible to stress ulcers, which could lead to gastrointestinal bleeding and other complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-inch tall, 118.3 kg (obese) individual who suffered a cardiac arrest, underwent tracheostomy, and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) for management of bilateral compartment syndrome and rhabdomyolysis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C (99.4°F), heart rate of 71 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure of 129/71 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute (bpm). The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 15 cmH2O, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of creatine kinase (CK) and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), indicating ongoing rhabdomyolysis. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia.

The patient's physical examination reveals right conjunctival edema, bilateral compartment syndrome with diminished pulses, and abdominal distension with decreased bowel sounds.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to rhabdomyolysis and hypovolemia.
2. Respiratory failure due to ongoing compartment syndrome and potential pulmonary embolism.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalances and rhabdomyolysis.
4. Sepsis or septic shock due to potential infection and rhabdomyolysis.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to hypovolemia and rhabdomyolysis.
6. Neurological complications such as seizures, stroke, or spinal cord compression due to compartment syndrome and rhabdomyolysis.

The patient's treatment plan should focus on managing their compartment syndrome, rhabdomyolysis, and electrolyte imbalances. This may involve ongoing mechanical ventilation, fluid resuscitation, and correction of electrolyte imbalances. The patient's laboratory results should be closely monitored for signs of AKI, and the patient should be assessed for potential complications such as sepsis, gastrointestinal bleeding, and neurological complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment & Plan:63 y/o M with PMHX of MM s/p autologous stem cell
   transplant in 05 presented foot pain and elevated CKs taken the OR
   emergently for fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome, now s/p cardiac
   arrest and emergency tracheotomy.
   .
   # s/p Cardiac Arrest: Etiology unclear, s/p epinephrine x1, CPR for 3
   minutes, may have been due to acute upper airway swelling and hypoxia
   causing cardiac arrest/bradycardia. Pt had rapid return of perfusing
   rhythm.  There was significant concern for initial poor neurologic
   status post code, however, pt has now had return of neuro function and
   following commands. Suspect that meds given peri code contributed to
   poor neuro status initially, now clearing.
   - replete lytes aggressively, pt is hyponatremic, still unclear
   etiology
   - serially neuro exams
   - would like to elucidate etiology of cardiac arrest better
 most
   likely etiology is hypoxia, with history of upper airway swelling would
   consider allergy/angioedema, would also consider PE as well as
   hypotension, sepsis
   - cooling protocol was deferred secondary to improving neuro exams
   - echo from yesterday did not show any evidence of right heart strain,
   mild LV hypertrophy, LVEF 50-55% with dilated aortic root, ascending
   aorta moderately dilated, small pericardial effusion
   - goal is to maintain MAP > 60 and maintain urine output > 100 cc/hr
   .
   # Resp failure: Pt was transferred to ICU s/p cardiac arrest with
   emergency trach and was initially requiring alot of support from vent
   to maintain oxygenation but now weaning quickly.  There was likely a
   component of negative inspiratory pressure pulm edema as seen by
   perihilar fullness on CXR.  This is also suggested by the fact that pt
   weaning quickly from initially high O2 requirement. Also with some
   increased secretions from emergency trach and blood in airways.
   Etiology of tongue swelling early on [**10-1**] and impressive upper airway
   edema seen by Anesthesia impeding the ability to re-intubate is
   unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 11**] have some component of airway collapse and tongue swelling
   from hypothyroidism. Baseline, pt is a Mallampati class III and may
   have pharyngeal airway collapse complicating picture.  Now have
   definite airway with trach, will hold off on steroids for now given
   immunosuppression.
   - cont hypoxia may be secondary to atelectasis vs. fluid overload
   secondary to volume repletion vs. Pulmonary embolus
   - wean oxygen/PEEP as tolerated however gases have been limiting us
   overnight (mental status is not a barrier to extubation)
   - will bring PEEP to 10 this morning
   - echo today to rule out blown RV which might indicate PE to explain
   etiology of hypoxia
   - continue aggressive suction
   - decreased RR to improve respiratory alkalosis, new ph 7.44
   - empiric Abx Vanc/Cefepime/Clinda/Doxy for any possible pericode &
   emergency trach aspiration
   - Alb/atrovent nebs
   - NPO for now, working on SBT with trach collar in AM
   .
   # Compartment Syndrome with abscess: Pt has now had definitive surgical
   intervention with fasciotomy and frank pus found after opening
   compartments.  Deep cultures were sent intra-op
   - continue Vanc/Cefepime/clinda for skin flora and ?immunocomp state,
   will cover gram negatives until cultures return, then narrow Abx
   - appreciate ID recs
 ID thinks that this might be a global process,
   reccomending west [**Doctor First Name **] serologies, stool enterovirus, ebv viral load,
   ebv, cmv, hav, hbv, hcv, lyme [**Doctor Last Name 376**] serologies  - HIV testing
   then consider viral load, also MRI
   - if goes to OR would consider muscle biopsy, repeat bacterial cx,
   viral cv
   - f/u cultures, try to get viral cx
   - dressing changes per Vascular
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Pt presented with hyponatremia of unclear etiology, may
   all be secondary to hypothyroidism.  Appears clinically euvolemic to
   hypervolemic currently, no prior h/o SIADH.  Pt having alot of urine
   output currently, it is possible that this hyponatremia & hypochloremia
   is due to volume overload.
   - continue NS IVF
   - serial lytes q6hrs
   - f/u urine lytes & osms
   - continue to treat hypothyroidism
   .
   # Multiple Myelomma: Pt has been on Revlimid which may have been
   contributing to hypothyroidism on admission.  Anemia & thrombocytopenia
   on admission likely due to marrow suppression.
   - holding Revlimid currently
   - f/u Onc recs
   .
   # Elevated CK/Rhabdo: This was likely all secondary to compartment
   syndrome with intracompartment abcess, now s/p fasciotomy
   - continue aggressive IVF, keep UOP>100cc/hr
   - monitor creatinine & f/u renal recs
   - continue local wound care per vasc
   .
   # LFT abnormalities: Elevated transaminases & elevated LDH in setting
   of acute rhabdo. Baseline LFTs normal.  Unclear if this is due to
   atypical infection vs acute rhabdo. Suspect that may continue to worsen
   today as patient is s/p cardiac arrest.
   - trend LFTs
   - f/u hepatitis serologies
   - f/u ID recs & atypical infection work up
   .
   # Anemia: Hct was 34.7 on admission, now down to 21. s/p 1 unit
   transfusion overnight.This is likely complicated by underlying abnormal
   bone marrow on revlimid for MM and intra-operative blood loss.
   - will transfuse another unit this AM, re-check crit and consider
   furthur
   - transfuse to maintain hct>25
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Pt profoundly hypothyroid with TSH>50 and low T4.
   This may be contributing to tongue swelling on admission.
   -          continue Levothyroxine 200mg IV daily
   -          endocrine does not think hypothyoidism is the etiology of
   patient
s presentation
   -          cortisol level pending
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now
   - NG tube today, nutrtion consult for tube feeds
   - NS fluid 150 cc/hr to maintain UOP > 100 cc/hr
   - aggressive repletion of lytes
   .
   # Access: Right femoral line placed during code under non-sterile
   conditions, 22 and 20 IV
   -          PICC line today, plan to d/c fem line pending picc line
   placement and stable blood pressure
   -          Consider central line for better access
   .
   # PPx: Pneumoboots, H2 Blocker, Colace, mouth care
   .
   # Code: FULL
   .
   # Dispo: ICU
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male who presented with foot pain and elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels, leading to an emergency fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome. He subsequently experienced cardiac arrest, requiring epinephrine and CPR, and was intubated and tracheotomized. The patient has been in the ICU for several days, receiving treatment for compartment syndrome, cardiac arrest, and respiratory failure. He has also been diagnosed with hyponatremia, anemia, rhabdomyolysis, and elevated liver enzymes.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is a concern, with a history of respiratory failure and ongoing hypoxia. He may require continued mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and subsequent treatment with epinephrine and CPR may have caused cardiac damage, leading to potential complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac tamponade.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and hypoxic episode may have caused neurological damage, leading to potential complications such as seizures, cognitive impairment, or paralysis.
4. Infection: The patient's compartment syndrome and fasciotomy may have introduced bacteria into his body, leading to potential infections such as sepsis or abscesses.
5. Kidney damage: The patient's rhabdomyolysis and compartment syndrome may have caused kidney damage, leading to potential complications such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
6. Liver damage: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may indicate liver damage, potentially leading to complications such as liver failure or cirrhosis.
7. Thyroid complications: The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen or lead to complications such as thyroid storm or myxedema coma.
8. Nutritional complications: The patient's inability to eat or drink may lead to malnutrition, dehydration, or electrolyte imbalances.
9. Wound complications: The patient's fasciotomy and tracheotomy may lead to wound complications such as infection, dehiscence, or bleeding.
10. Blood clotting complications: The patient's anemia and compartment syndrome may increase his risk of developing blood clots, potentially leading to complications such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address these potential complications and ensure his optimal care.

   Assessment & Plan:63 y/o M with PMHX of MM s/p autologous stem cell

   emergently for fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome, now s/p cardiac
   arrest and emergency tracheotomy.
   .

   emergency trach and was initially requiring alot of support from vent
   to maintain oxygenation but now weaning quickly.  There was likely a
   component of negative inspiratory pressure pulm edema as seen by
   perihilar fullness on CXR.  This is also suggested by the fact that pt
   weaning quickly from initially high O2 requirement. Also with some
   increased secretions from emergency trach and blood in airways.
   Etiology of tongue swelling early on [**10-1**] and impressive upper airway
   edema seen by Anesthesia impeding the ability to re-intubate is
   unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 11**] have some component of airway collapse and tongue swelling
   from hypothyroidism. Baseline, pt is a Mallampati class III and may
   have pharyngeal airway collapse complicating picture.  Now have
   definite airway with trach, will hold off on steroids for now given
   immunosuppression.
   - no evidence of right heart strain on echo to suggest PE
   - patient was weaned off ventilator, now just using trach, mental
   status and respiratory drive good
   - continue aggressive suction
   - will need trach cuff change to smaller size when appropriate
   - Alb/atrovent nebs
   .
   # s/p Cardiac Arrest: Etiology unclear, s/p epinephrine x1, CPR for 3
   minutes, may have been due to acute upper airway swelling and hypoxia
   causing cardiac arrest/bradycardia. Pt had rapid return of perfusing
   rhythm.  There was significant concern for initial poor neurologic
   status post code, however, pt has now had return of neuro function and
   following commands. Suspect that meds given peri code contributed to
   poor neuro status initially, now clearing.
   - persistently low Calcium despite repletion, continue aggressive
   repletion
   - patient is now awake, alert, responsive
   - etiology of arrest likely hypoxia, with upper airway swelling likely
   secondary to myxedema from hypothryoidism
   - echo from yesterday did not show any evidence of right heart strain,
   mild LV hypertrophy, LVEF 50-55% with dilated aortic root, ascending
   aorta moderately dilated, small pericardial effusion
   - goal is to maintain MAP > 60 and maintain urine output > 100 cc/hr

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male who presented with foot pain and elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels, leading to an emergency fasciotomy and compartment release. He subsequently experienced cardiac arrest, was intubated, and underwent a tracheotomy. He was transferred to the ICU where he is currently being weaned off the ventilator. The patient has a history of multiple myeloma, hypothyroidism, and has been taking Revlimid, which may have contributed to his hypothyroidism.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Compartment syndrome with abscess: The patient had a fasciotomy and compartment release, and frank pus was found in the compartments.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient experienced a cardiac arrest, which was likely caused by hypoxia and upper airway swelling.
3. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient has persistently elevated CK levels, which may be secondary to the compartment syndrome and rhabdomyolysis.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, which may be secondary to hypothyroidism or effective volume depletion.
5. Elevated LFTs: The patient has elevated liver function tests (LFTs), which may be secondary to acute rhabdomyolysis or an atypical infection.
6. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may be complicated by underlying abnormal bone marrow on Revlimid for MM and intra-operative blood loss.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient has profound hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to his tongue swelling and other symptoms.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient may experience respiratory failure due to his compromised respiratory status and the need for ongoing respiratory support.
2. Sepsis: The patient may develop sepsis due to the abscess and the presence of bacteria in the bloodstream.
3. Renal failure: The patient may experience renal failure due to the rhabdomyolysis and the need for ongoing fluid resuscitation.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient may experience cardiac arrhythmias due to his underlying cardiac condition and the need for ongoing cardiac monitoring.
5. Infection: The patient may develop an infection due to the presence of bacteria in the bloodstream and the need for ongoing antibiotic therapy.
6. Bleeding: The patient may experience bleeding due to his compromised coagulation status and the need for ongoing transfusions.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient may experience gastrointestinal bleeding due to the need for ongoing nasogastric suction and the presence of stress ulcers.

The patient's ongoing care should focus on:

1. Aggressive fluid resuscitation to maintain adequate blood pressure and urine output.
2. Ongoing respiratory support to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
3. Antibiotic therapy to cover potential infections and prevent sepsis.
4. Aggressive wound care to promote healing and prevent infection.
5. Ongoing cardiac monitoring to detect any cardiac arrhythmias or other cardiac complications.
6. Regular laboratory testing to monitor the patient's liver and renal function, as well as his electrolyte levels.
7. Regular assessments of the patient's neurological status to monitor for any changes or deterioration.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma, who experienced rhabdo and cardiac arrest, requiring repeat fasciotomy and subsequent ICU admission.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory support: Off ventilator and on trach shield with CPAP/PSV mode, set Vt 550 mL, PS 5 cmH2O, PEEP 5 cmH2O, FiO2 50%, and SpO2 95%.
* Cardiovascular: Heart rhythm is sinus rhythm, with a blood pressure of 121/67 mmHg and a heart rate of 81 bpm.
* Neurological: Not assessed due to patient's condition.
* Renal: No specific information available.
* Hematology: Patient has a history of multiple myeloma.
* Infection: Patient has a low-grade temperature overnight, and vancomycin has been discontinued, but other antibiotics will be continued for now.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is currently stable, but there is a risk of further deterioration, particularly if the patient develops pneumonia or other respiratory infections.
* Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's CPK levels are trending up, and there is a risk of further muscle damage and kidney injury if the patient does not receive adequate treatment.
* Infection: The patient's low-grade temperature overnight suggests the possibility of infection, and there is a risk of further infection if the patient's immune system is compromised.
* Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and may be at risk for further cardiac complications, particularly if the patient develops arrhythmias or other cardiac issues.
* Renal failure: The patient's history of multiple myeloma and rhabdomyolysis puts them at risk for renal failure, particularly if the patient does not receive adequate treatment.
* Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutritional status is not well-documented, and there is a risk of nutritional deficiencies if the patient does not receive adequate nutrition.
* Blood clotting disorders: The patient's history of multiple myeloma and rhabdomyolysis puts them at risk for blood clotting disorders, particularly if the patient develops disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and treatment to manage their respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological status, as well as to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma who underwent repeat fasciotomy on the right side. He is currently in the ICU with several ongoing medical issues.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.5°C (99.5°F), heart rate of 81 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 121/67 mmHg. His respiratory support includes a tracheostomy tube and CPAP/PSV ventilator mode.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of creatine phosphokinase (CPK), indicating rhabdomyolysis. His liver enzymes are also elevated, with an alanine transaminase (ALT) level of 294 IU/L and an aspartate transaminase (AST) level of 568 IU/L.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Acute respiratory failure: The patient is now off ventilator and on trach shield.
2. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's CPK levels are trending up, and he will continue to receive fluids with bicarbonate until his CPK levels decrease.
3. Low-grade temperature overnight: The patient's vancomycin will be discontinued, and he will continue to be monitored for fevers.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further worsening of rhabdomyolysis, leading to acute kidney injury or cardiac complications.
* Development of pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to the patient's prolonged respiratory support.
* Increased risk of bleeding due to the patient's elevated creatine phosphokinase (CPK) levels.
* Potential for further liver enzyme elevation, leading to liver dysfunction.
* Risk of sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's low-grade temperature and elevated inflammatory markers.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent or mitigate these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma (MM) who underwent autologous stem cell transplant in 2016. He was admitted to the ICU with bilateral compartment syndrome, tracheal swelling, and profound hypothyroidism likely secondary to statin use. The patient is currently receiving invasive ventilation, and his vital signs are stable. He is agitated and refusing to cooperate with the examination.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antacids, and infusions. His lab results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and liver enzymes. He has also been diagnosed with acute kidney injury, and his blood pressure is slightly elevated.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's bilateral compartment syndrome and tracheal swelling may lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Hypothyroidism: The patient's profound hypothyroidism may lead to further complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, if not treated promptly.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and decreased urine output may indicate acute kidney injury, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and platelet count may indicate an underlying infection, which can lead to sepsis if not treated promptly.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated blood pressure and cardiac enzymes may indicate cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or infarction, if not managed properly.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's agitation and refusal to cooperate with the examination may indicate neurological complications, such as cerebral edema or seizures, if not managed properly.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment & Plan:63 y/o M with PMHX of MM s/p autologous stem cell
   transplant in 05 presented foot pain and elevated CKs taken the OR
   emergently for fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome, now s/p cardiac
   arrest and emergency tracheotomy.
   .
   # Resp failure: Pt was transferred to ICU s/p cardiac arrest with
   emergency trach and was initially requiring alot of support from vent
   to maintain oxygenation but now weaning quickly.  There was likely a
   component of negative inspiratory pressure pulm edema as seen by
   perihilar fullness on CXR.  This is also suggested by the fact that pt
   weaning quickly from initially high O2 requirement. Also with some
   increased secretions from emergency trach and blood in airways.
   Etiology of tongue swelling early on [**10-1**] and impressive upper airway
   edema seen by Anesthesia impeding the ability to re-intubate is
   unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 11**] have some component of airway collapse and tongue swelling
   from hypothyroidism. Baseline, pt is a Mallampati class III and may
   have pharyngeal airway collapse complicating picture.  Now have
   definite airway with trach, will hold off on steroids for now given
   immunosuppression.
   - no evidence of right heart strain on echo to suggest PE
   - patient was weaned off ventilator, now just using trach, mental
   status and respiratory drive good
   - continue aggressive suction
   - will need trach cuff change to smaller size which cannot occur until
   7-14 days after initial trach placement
   - Alb/atrovent nebs
   .
   # s/p Cardiac Arrest: Etiology unclear, s/p epinephrine x1, CPR for 3
   minutes, may have been due to acute upper airway swelling and hypoxia
   causing cardiac arrest/bradycardia. Pt had rapid return of perfusing
   rhythm.  There was significant concern for initial poor neurologic
   status post code, however, pt has now had return of neuro function and
   following commands. Suspect that meds given peri code contributed to
   poor neuro status initially, now clearing.
   - persistently low Calcium despite repletion, continue aggressive
   repletion
   - patient is now awake, alert, responsive
   - etiology of arrest likely hypoxia, with upper airway swelling likely
   secondary to myxedema from hypothryoidism
   - echo did not show any evidence of right heart strain, mild LV
   hypertrophy, LVEF 50-55% with dilated aortic root, ascending aorta
   moderately dilated, small pericardial effusion
   - goal is to maintain MAP > 60 and maintain urine output > 100 cc/hr
   # Compartment Syndrome with abscess: Pt has now had definitive surgical
   intervention with fasciotomy and frank pus found after opening
   compartments.  Deep cultures were sent intra-op
   - now s/p fasciotomy to right leg as well for elevated pressures
   - continue Cefepime for skin flora and ?immunocomp state, will cover
   gram negatives until cultures return, then narrow Abx
   - culture data all no growth to date, peeled off vancomycin yesterday,
   will d/c clindamycin todaoy
   - west [**Doctor First Name **] serology pending, stool enterovirus pending, ebv viral
   load, ebv, cmv, hav, hbv, hcv, lyme [**Doctor Last Name 376**] serologies
   - see below for furthru infectious etiology
   - dressing changes per Vascular
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Pt presented with hyponatremia likely  secondary to
   hypothyroidism or from effective volume depletion, in the setting of
   compartment syndomre.
   -hyponatremia improved today
   - continue NS IVF at 100cc/hr
   - urine lytes
 Urea 257 Cr 51 Na 13 K 31
   - serum osms 258
   - continue to treat hypothyroidism, as per endocrine will continue
   current dosing
   .
   # Multiple Myelomma: Pt has been on Revlimid which may have been
   contributing to hypothyroidism on admission.  Anemia & thrombocytopenia
   on admission likely due to marrow suppression from treatment.
   - holding Revlimid currently
   - f/u Onc recs
   .
   # Elevated CK/Rhabdo: This was likely all secondary to compartment
   syndrome with intracompartment abcess, now s/p fasciotomy
   - continue aggressive IVF,  given persistently elevated CKs, previously
   alkalinization of the urine leading to elevated pH, now switched back
   to NS at 100 cc/hr
   - creatine has been stable, no evidence of acute renal failuer,
   follow-up renal recs
   - continue local wound care per vasc
   .
   Infectious work-up: Concern for infection as initial etiology of
   rhabdomylosis, completing full work-up as per ID.
   - wound culture from the OR:
GRAM STAIN (Final [**2165-10-1**]):
      NO POLYMORPHONUCLEAR LEUKOCYTES SEEN.
      NO MICROORGANISMS SEEN.
WOUND CULTURE (Final [**2165-10-3**]):    NO GROWTH.
ANAEROBIC CULTURE (Preliminary):    NO GROWTH.
ACID FAST SMEAR (Final [**2165-10-2**]):
      NO ACID FAST BACILLI SEEN ON DIRECT SMEAR.
ACID FAST CULTURE (Preliminary):
FUNGAL CULTURE (Preliminary):
      NO FUNGUS ISOLATED.
      A swab is not the optimal specimen for recovery of mycobacteria or
      filamentous fungi.  A negative result should be interpreted with
      caution.  Whenever possible tissue biopsy or aspirated fluid should
      be submitted.
   -west nile virus pending
   - cmv pending
   Stool viral culture pending
   Throat viral culture pending
   hepC antibody negative
   hep A antibody POS
   from [**2162**], hep B surfaceb Ab +, hep B core antibody POS
   -          sputum culture
 > 25 PMNs, < 10 Epis, 1+ yeast
   -          urine cx  NG
   -          muscle cx from OR
 no virus isolated so far
   # LFT abnormalities: Elevated transaminases & elevated LDH in setting
   of acute rhabdo. Baseline LFTs normal but does have history of +
   hepatitis B in the past, now with + hep A antibody, unclear if IgM or
   IgG at this point.  Etiology of elevated LFTs is either viral vs.
   secondary to rhabdomylsis. Suspect that may continue to worsen today as
   patient is s/p cardiac arrest.
   - hep A antibody [**Last Name (LF) 400**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] send for IgM levels
   - LFTs remain elevated in the setting of continued CK elevation, which
   may be muscle only
   - remainder of hep serologies pending
   - ID work- up as above
   - tox screen negative
   .
   # Anemia: Hct was 34.7 on admission, which has trended down .This is
   likely complicated by underlying abnormal bone marrow on revlimid for
   MM and intra-operative blood loss.
   - will continue to transfuse and try to maintainhct>25
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Pt profoundly hypothyroid with TSH>50 and low T4.
   This may be contributing to tongue swelling on admission.
   -          continue Levothyroxine 200mg IV daily
   -          think that profound hypothyroidism in the context of statin
   use may have caused presentation
   -          will check repeat TSH, free T3, free T4 in 1 week, cortisol
   level WNL
   -          tapering steroids as per endocrine
   .
   # FEN:
   - speech/swallow eval cleared patient for thin liquids and soft
   dysphagic diet, however patient is requesting pureed diet as right now
   he doesn
t have his dentures
   - can advance diet to dysphagic once patient has dentures
   - NS fluid 150 cc/hr to maintain UOP > 100 cc/hr
   - aggressive repletion of lytes
   .
   # Access:
   -          - currently with PICC line, 1 peripheral IV, previously had
   right femoral line placed during code under non-sterile conditions
   during code which was removed
   .
   # PPx: Pneumoboots, H2 Blocker, Colace, mouth care
   .
   # Code: FULL
   .
   # Dispo: Consider transfer to floor today
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male who presented to the ICU with foot pain, elevated CKs, and bilateral compartment syndrome. He underwent emergent fasciotomy and tracheotomy due to cardiac arrest and upper airway edema. The patient has a history of multiple myeloma and autologous stem cell transplant in 2005. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been weaned off the ventilator. The patient has multiple medical conditions, including hypothyroidism, rhabdomyolysis, anemia, and elevated LFTs.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation. The risk of respiratory failure is high due to his underlying medical conditions and the presence of compartment syndrome.
2. Cardiac Arrest: The patient has already experienced cardiac arrest, and there is a high risk of recurrent cardiac arrest due to his underlying medical conditions and the presence of upper airway edema.
3. Infection: The patient has a high risk of infection due to his compromised immune system and the presence of compartment syndrome. The patient's wound culture has shown no growth, but further cultures are pending.
4. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's rhabdomyolysis is likely secondary to compartment syndrome, but it may also be exacerbated by his underlying medical conditions. The patient's CK levels are still elevated, and he may require continued aggressive IV fluids and electrolyte repletion.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism is likely contributing to his respiratory and cardiac instability. He requires continued thyroid hormone replacement therapy, and his TSH levels should be monitored closely.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to his underlying bone marrow suppression and intra-operative blood loss. He may require continued transfusions to maintain a hemoglobin level > 25.
7. LFT Abnormalities: The patient's LFT abnormalities are likely secondary to rhabdomyolysis and may also be exacerbated by his underlying medical conditions. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of his LFT abnormalities.
8. Inflammatory Response: The patient's inflammatory response is likely elevated due to his underlying medical conditions and the presence of compartment syndrome. He may require continued aggressive treatment with anti-inflammatory medications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider tracheotomy if necessary.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and consider cardiac arrest protocols if necessary.
3. Continue to evaluate the patient for infection and consider broad-spectrum antibiotics if necessary.
4. Continue to treat the patient's rhabdomyolysis with aggressive IV fluids and electrolyte repletion.
5. Continue to treat the patient's hypothyroidism with thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
6. Continue to transfuse the patient to maintain a hemoglobin level > 25.
7. Continue to evaluate the patient's LFT abnormalities and consider further testing if necessary.
8. Consider anti-inflammatory medications to treat the patient's inflammatory response.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma who presented to the ICU with bilateral compartment syndrome, tracheal swelling, and profound hypothyroidism. He was initially intubated and required mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He underwent emergency tracheotomy and fasciotomy, and was found to have frank pus in the compartments. He was also diagnosed with rhabdomyolysis, hyponatremia, and elevated liver enzymes. He was treated with antibiotics, steroids, and other medications to manage his conditions.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is a concern, as he was initially intubated and required mechanical ventilation. He was weaned off the ventilator, but still requires oxygen therapy. There is a risk of respiratory failure if his oxygenation and ventilation do not improve.
2. Compartment syndrome: The patient's compartment syndrome is a significant concern, as it can lead to further tissue damage and potentially life-threatening complications. He requires ongoing management of his compartments to prevent further damage.
3. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's rhabdomyolysis is a concern, as it can lead to kidney damage and potentially life-threatening complications. He requires ongoing management of his rhabdomyolysis, including aggressive hydration and alkalization of his urine.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is a concern, as it can lead to seizures and potentially life-threatening complications. He requires ongoing management of his hyponatremia, including administration of normal saline and close monitoring of his electrolyte levels.
5. Liver enzyme elevation: The patient's liver enzyme elevation is a concern, as it can indicate liver damage or dysfunction. He requires ongoing monitoring of his liver enzymes and management of any underlying liver disease.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism is a concern, as it can lead to a range of systemic symptoms and complications. He requires ongoing management of his hypothyroidism, including administration of thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is a concern, as it can lead to fatigue, weakness, and potentially life-threatening complications. He requires ongoing management of his anemia, including transfusion of blood products and management of any underlying bone marrow dysfunction.
8. Infection: The patient's infection is a concern, as it can lead to a range of systemic symptoms and complications. He requires ongoing management of his infection, including administration of antibiotics and close monitoring of his vital signs and laboratory results.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment & Plan:63 y/o M with PMHX of MM s/p autologous stem cell
   transplant in 05 presented foot pain and elevated CKs taken the OR
   emergently for fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome, now s/p cardiac
   arrest and emergency tracheotomy.
   .
   # Resp failure: Pt was transferred to ICU s/p cardiac arrest with
   emergency trach and was initially requiring alot of support from vent
   to maintain oxygenation but now weaning quickly.  There was likely a
   component of negative inspiratory pressure pulm edema as seen by
   perihilar fullness on CXR.  This is also suggested by the fact that pt
   weaning quickly from initially high O2 requirement. Also with some
   increased secretions from emergency trach and blood in airways.
   Etiology of tongue swelling early on [**10-1**] and impressive upper airway
   edema seen by Anesthesia impeding the ability to re-intubate is
   unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 11**] have some component of airway collapse and tongue swelling
   from hypothyroidism. Baseline, pt is a Mallampati class III and may
   have pharyngeal airway collapse complicating picture.  Now have
   definite airway with trach, will hold off on steroids for now given
   immunosuppression.
   - no evidence of right heart strain on echo to suggest PE
   - patient was weaned off ventilator, now just using trach, mental
   status and respiratory drive good
   - continue aggressive suction
   - will need trach cuff change to smaller size when appropriate
   - Alb/atrovent nebs
   .
   # s/p Cardiac Arrest: Etiology unclear, s/p epinephrine x1, CPR for 3
   minutes, may have been due to acute upper airway swelling and hypoxia
   causing cardiac arrest/bradycardia. Pt had rapid return of perfusing
   rhythm.  There was significant concern for initial poor neurologic
   status post code, however, pt has now had return of neuro function and
   following commands. Suspect that meds given peri code contributed to
   poor neuro status initially, now clearing.
   - persistently low Calcium despite repletion, continue aggressive
   repletion
   - patient is now awake, alert, responsive
   - etiology of arrest likely hypoxia, with upper airway swelling likely
   secondary to myxedema from hypothryoidism
   - echo from yesterday did not show any evidence of right heart strain,
   mild LV hypertrophy, LVEF 50-55% with dilated aortic root, ascending
   aorta moderately dilated, small pericardial effusion
   - goal is to maintain MAP > 60 and maintain urine output > 100 cc/hr
   # Compartment Syndrome with abscess: Pt has now had definitive surgical
   intervention with fasciotomy and frank pus found after opening
   compartments.  Deep cultures were sent intra-op
   - now s/p fasciotomy to right leg as well for elevated pressures
   - continue Cefepime/clinda for skin flora and ?immunocomp state, will
   cover gram negatives until cultures return, then narrow Abx
   - d/c Vancomycin at this time as no evidence of gram + infection
   - as per ID do not think that overall etiology is infectious, however
   recommending west [**Doctor First Name **] serology which is pending, stool enterovirus -
   pending, ebv viral load, ebv, cmv, hav, hbv, hcv, lyme [**Doctor Last Name 376**]
   serologies
   - consider hiv testing
   - ordered urine viral culture and well as respiratory viral culture
   - dressing changes per Vascular
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Pt presented with hyponatremia likely  secondary to
   hypothyroidism or from effective volume depletion, secondary to
   multiple surgeries.  Pt currently with good urine output.
   - continue NS IVF
   - urine lytes
 Urea 257 Cr 51 Na 13 K 31
   - serum osms 258
   - continue to treat hypothyroidism, will call endocrine to assess
   whether or not patient needs increase in dose
   .
   # Multiple Myelomma: Pt has been on Revlimid which may have been
   contributing to hypothyroidism on admission.  Anemia & thrombocytopenia
   on admission likely due to marrow suppression.
   - holding Revlimid currently
   - f/u Onc recs
   .
   # Elevated CK/Rhabdo: This was likely all secondary to compartment
   syndrome with intracompartment abcess, now s/p fasciotomy
   - continue aggressive IVF,  given persistently elevated CKs, will
   alkalinize the urine despite mildly elevated pH, give 200 cc/hr and
   goal to keep UOP>100cc/hr
   - creatine has been stable, will continue to follow-up renal recs
   - continue local wound care per vasc
   .
   Infectious work-up

      A swab is not the optimal specimen for recovery of mycobacteria or

   -west nile virus pending

   hepC antibody negative
   hep A antibody POS
   from [**2162**], hep B surfaceb Ab +, hep B core antibody POS
   -          sputum culture
 > 25 PMNs, < 10 Epis, 1+ yeast
   -          urine cx  NG
   -          muscle cx from OR
 no virus isolated so far
   # LFT abnormalities: Elevated transaminases & elevated LDH in setting
   of acute rhabdo. Baseline LFTs normal but does have history of +
   hepatitis B in the past, now with + hep A antibody, unclear if IgM or
   IgG at this point.  Etiology of elevated LFTs is either viral vs.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's initial respiratory failure may recur due to ongoing hypothyroidism and potential upper airway edema.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient's recent cardiac arrest may be due to hypoxia, upper airway swelling, and/or hypothyroidism. Further cardiac complications may arise if the underlying conditions are not adequately managed.
3. Compartment syndrome: The patient's compartment syndrome may lead to further tissue damage, necrosis, and potential sepsis if not properly managed.
4. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and recent surgical interventions increase the risk of infection. The patient's wound culture results are pending, and the possibility of a deep-seated infection cannot be ruled out.
5. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's ongoing rhabdomyolysis may lead to further muscle damage, electrolyte imbalances, and potential renal failure if not managed aggressively.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to potential seizures, coma, or even death.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to potential cardiac complications and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient's profound hypothyroidism may lead to further complications, such as decreased cardiac output, respiratory failure, and potential cardiac arrest.
9. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's recent cardiac arrest and respiratory failure may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as ileus or gastrointestinal bleeding.
10. Neurological complications: The patient's recent cardiac arrest and respiratory failure may lead to potential neurological complications, such as stroke, seizures, or cognitive impairment.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and manage these potential complications aggressively to prevent further deterioration and improve the patient's outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-inch tall, 118.3 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with a tracheostomy in place and unable to talk. Overnight, the patient experienced changes in mental status, but these have improved. The patient is currently on invasive ventilation, but it was stopped 24 hours ago. The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, and has a history of rhabdomyolysis, respiratory failure, transient delirium, and hypothyroidism.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's history of rhabdomyolysis, likely secondary to statins, may lead to further muscle damage and potential kidney failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of respiratory failure may lead to further complications, such as pneumonia, respiratory acidosis, or respiratory failure.
3. Transient delirium: The patient's transient delirium, likely secondary to steroids, may lead to further cognitive impairment or agitation.
4. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may lead to further complications, such as fatigue, weakness, or cold intolerance.
5. Infections: The patient's history of antibiotics and potential catheter-related infections may lead to further complications, such as sepsis or endocarditis.
6. Fluid imbalance: The patient's fluid balance is slightly positive, which may lead to further complications, such as fluid overload or cardiac failure.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are slightly abnormal, which may lead to further complications, such as muscle weakness, cardiac arrhythmias, or seizures.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of antibiotics and potential gastrointestinal infections may lead to further complications, such as diarrhea, constipation, or gastrointestinal bleeding.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and address these potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient's mental status has changed overnight, with no known triggers or events reported. The patient is receiving invasive ventilation, which was stopped at 11:00 AM. The patient is receiving multiple antibiotics, including vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, clindamycin, doxycycline, and cefipime. The patient is also receiving other ICU medications, including famotidine.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 81 bpm, and blood pressure of 132/66 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98%. The patient's blood work shows elevated levels of creatine kinase, lactate dehydrogenase, and troponin-T, suggesting rhabdomyolysis.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the patient's unstable mental status and lack of response to stimuli. The patient's skin, neurologic, and peripheral vascular examinations are not assessed.

The patient's lab results show:

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Rhabdomyolysis: likely secondary to statins in the background, plan to continue normal saline and monitor for further changes.
2. Hypothyroidism: plan to decrease steroid dose and continue synthroid.
3. ID: plan to discuss with ID and continue to de-escalate antibiotics.
4. ICU care: plan to continue ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and line management.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening rhabdomyolysis and kidney damage due to prolonged use of statins and antibiotics.
* Hypothyroidism complications, such as decreased cardiac output, decreased body temperature, and increased risk of infection.
* ID complications, such as sepsis, septic shock, and organ failure.
* ICU-acquired complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, central line-associated bloodstream infection, and pressure ulcers.
* Nutritional deficiencies and malnutrition due to inadequate nutrition.
* Hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia due to inadequate glycemic control.
* Line-related complications, such as bleeding, infection, and thrombosis.

   Assessment & Plan:63 y/o M with PMHX of MM s/p autologous stem cell
   transplant in 05 presented foot pain and elevated CKs taken the OR
   emergently for fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome, now s/p cardiac
   arrest and emergency tracheotomy.
   # Resp failure: Pt was transferred to ICU s/p cardiac arrest with
   emergency trach and was initially requiring alot of support from vent
   to maintain oxygenation but now weaning quickly.  There was likely a
   component of negative inspiratory pressure pulm edema as seen by
   perihilar fullness on CXR.  This is also suggested by the fact that pt
   weaning quickly from initially high O2 requirement. Also with some
   increased secretions from emergency trach and blood in airways.
   Etiology of tongue swelling early on [**10-1**] and impressive upper airway
   edema seen by Anesthesia impeding the ability to re-intubate is
   unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 11**] have some component of airway collapse and tongue swelling
   from hypothyroidism. Baseline, pt is a Mallampati class III and may
   have pharyngeal airway collapse complicating picture.  Now have
   definite airway with trach, will hold off on steroids for now given
   immunosuppression.
   - no evidence of right heart strain on echo to suggest PE
   - patient was weaned off ventilator, now just using trach, mental
   status and respiratory drive good
   - continue aggressive suction
   - will need trach cuff change to smaller size which cannot occur until
   7-14 days after initial trach placement
   - Alb/atrovent nebs
   # s/p Cardiac Arrest: Etiology unclear, s/p epinephrine x1, CPR for 3
   minutes, may have been due to acute upper airway swelling and hypoxia
   causing cardiac arrest/bradycardia. Pt had rapid return of perfusing
   rhythm.  There was significant concern for initial poor neurologic
   status post code, however, pt has now had return of neuro function and
   following commands. Suspect that meds given peri code contributed to
   poor neuro status initially, now clearing.
   - persistently low Calcium despite repletion, continue aggressive
   repletion
   - patient is now awake, alert, responsive
   - etiology of arrest likely hypoxia, with upper airway swelling likely
   secondary to myxedema from hypothryoidism
   - echo did not show any evidence of right heart strain, mild LV
   hypertrophy, LVEF 50-55% with dilated aortic root, ascending aorta
   moderately dilated, small pericardial effusion
   - goal is to maintain MAP > 60 and maintain urine output > 100 cc/hr
   # Compartment Syndrome with abscess: Pt has now had definitive surgical
   intervention with fasciotomy and frank pus found after opening
   compartments.  Deep cultures were sent intra-op
   - now s/p fasciotomy to right leg as well for elevated pressures
   - continue Cefepime for skin flora and ?immunocomp state, will cover
   gram negatives until cultures return, then narrow Abx
   - culture data all no growth to date, peeled off vancomycin yesterday,
   will d/c clindamycin todaoy
   - west [**Doctor First Name **] serology pending, stool enterovirus pending, ebv viral

   - see below for furthru infectious etiology
   - dressing changes per Vascular

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma who presented with foot pain and elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels. He was taken to the operating room emergently for fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome and was found to have frank pus in the compartments. He also had a cardiac arrest during the procedure and required emergency tracheotomy.

The patient is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) and is being treated for multiple medical conditions, including:

1. Hypothyroidism: The patient is profoundly hypothyroid with a TSH level >50 and low T4 levels. This may be contributing to his tongue swelling and other symptoms.
2. Compartment syndrome: The patient has had a fasciotomy procedure to relieve pressure in his legs and has been found to have frank pus in the compartments.
3. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient has elevated CK levels, which may be secondary to compartment syndrome and rhabdomyolysis.
4. Cardiac arrest: The patient had a cardiac arrest during the procedure and required epinephrine and CPR.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient required emergency tracheotomy and is currently on a tracheostomy mask.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, which may be secondary to hypothyroidism or effective volume depletion.
7. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may be secondary to his underlying bone marrow disorder and intra-operative blood loss.
8. LFT abnormalities: The patient has elevated transaminases and LDH levels, which may be secondary to viral or rhabdomyolysis-related liver injury.
9. Hepatitis: The patient has a history of hepatitis B and is currently positive for hepatitis A antibody.
10. Infectious work-up: The patient has had a full work-up for infection, including wound cultures, blood cultures, and viral cultures, which have been negative so far.

The patient is currently being treated with:

* Levothyroxine 200mg IV daily for hypothyroidism
* Cefepime for skin flora and potential immunocompromised state
* Aggressive repletion of electrolytes and fluids
* Aggressive suctioning to manage respiratory secretions
* Tracheostomy care
* Local wound care
* IV fluids and antibiotics as needed

The patient's goals include:

* Maintaining a MAP >60 and urine output >100 cc/hr
* Weaning off ventilator support
* Managing respiratory secretions
* Managing electrolyte imbalances
* Managing anemia and bleeding
* Managing LFT abnormalities
* Completing infectious work-up and treating any underlying infections

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest
* Infection
* Sepsis
* Liver failure
* Kidney failure
* Anemia and bleeding
* Hypothyroidism-related complications
* Rhabdomyolysis-related complications
* Compartment syndrome-related complications

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with profound hypothyroidism, compartment syndrome, and laryngeal swelling, leading to an emergency tracheotomy. He was found to have cardiac arrest and was resuscitated. He was also diagnosed with rhabdomyolysis, acute kidney injury, and elevated liver enzymes. The patient has undergone fasciotomy and drainage of abscesses, and has been treated with antibiotics and other medications. He is currently being managed in the ICU with mechanical ventilation, and is expected to be transferred to the floor today.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is currently stable, but he may still be at risk for respiratory failure due to his underlying hypothyroidism and compartment syndrome.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient has had a cardiac arrest, and may be at risk for another one due to his underlying cardiac condition and electrolyte imbalance.
3. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient has developed rhabdomyolysis, which can lead to acute kidney injury and other complications.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient has developed acute kidney injury, which may require further management and treatment.
5. Liver enzyme elevation: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may indicate liver damage or dysfunction.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient has profound hypothyroidism, which may require further management and treatment.
7. Compartment syndrome: The patient has compartment syndrome, which may require further management and treatment.
8. Infection: The patient has a high risk of infection due to his underlying condition and the presence of abscesses and wounds.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's cardiac condition and electrolyte imbalance.
3. Continue to treat the patient's rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's liver enzymes and adjust treatment as needed.
5. Continue to manage the patient's hypothyroidism and compartment syndrome.
6. Consider involving surgery in the management of the patient's abdominal condition.
7. Continue to monitor the patient for signs of infection and adjust treatment as needed.

Based on the daily progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a pulseless arrest and emergency tracheotomy. The patient has a history of multiple myeloma and was taking Revlimid, which may have contributed to his hypothyroidism.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is currently weaning off the ventilator and is using a tracheostomy tube. He has a Mallampati class III airway and may have pharyngeal airway collapse complicating the picture. The patient has been treated with aggressive suction and is currently receiving alb/atrovent nebs.
* Cardiac: The patient had a cardiac arrest and was treated with epinephrine and CPR. He has since had a rapid return of perfusing rhythm. The patient's cardiac status is currently stable, with a mild LV hypertrophy and LVEF of 50-55%.
* Neurological: The patient has had a return of neuro function and is following commands. His mental status and respiratory drive are good.
* Infectious: The patient has had a full work-up for infection, including wound cultures, which have shown no growth. He is being treated with Cefepime for skin flora and possible immunocompromised state.
* Renal: The patient has had a diagnosis of compartment syndrome with abscess, which has been treated with fasciotomy and frank pus found after opening the compartments. He is currently receiving aggressive IV fluid therapy.
* Hepatic: The patient has had elevated LFTs, which may be due to viral or secondary to rhabdomyolysis. He has a history of hepatitis B and is currently being treated with Levothyroxine for hypothyroidism.
* Hematological: The patient has had a diagnosis of anemia, which is likely complicated by underlying abnormal bone marrow on Revlimid for MM and intra-operative blood loss.
* Endocrine: The patient has had a diagnosis of hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to his tongue swelling. He is currently being treated with Levothyroxine.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is currently stable, but he may require further treatment with aggressive suction and nebs.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient had a cardiac arrest and was treated with epinephrine and CPR. He may be at risk for further cardiac complications.
* Infection: The patient has had a full work-up for infection, but he may still be at risk for developing an infection, particularly in the setting of immunocompromised state.
* Renal failure: The patient has had a diagnosis of compartment syndrome with abscess, which may have caused acute renal failure.
* Hepatic failure: The patient has had elevated LFTs, which may be due to viral or secondary to rhabdomyolysis. He may be at risk for further hepatic complications.
* Hematological complications: The patient has had a diagnosis of anemia, which may be complicated by underlying abnormal bone marrow on Revlimid for MM and intra-operative blood loss.
* Endocrine complications: The patient has had a diagnosis of hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to his tongue swelling. He may be at risk for further endocrine complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing aggressive suction and nebs for respiratory support
* Maintaining a MAP > 60 and urine output > 100 cc/hr
* Continuing Cefepime for skin flora and possible immunocompromised state
* Monitoring for signs of infection and adjusting treatment as necessary
* Continuing Levothyroxine for hypothyroidism
* Monitoring for signs of cardiac complications and adjusting treatment as necessary
* Continuing aggressive IV fluid therapy for renal support
* Monitoring for signs of hepatic complications and adjusting treatment as necessary
* Continuing to transfuse and try to maintain Hct > 25 for anemia
* Monitoring for signs of endocrine complications and adjusting treatment as necessary

The patient's disposition is being considered for transfer to the floor today.
